##

::: {.incremental}

- Geographical stroke units offer effective treatment for ischemic and hemorrhagic stroke patients. 
- Optimal care is achieved when patients are allocated to these wards. Estimating the optimum number of beds required is a complex task. 

:::

# <span> Conclusion </span> {background-image="d-a-v-i-d-s-o-n-l-u-n-a-KeGToDVN0l4-unsplash.jpg" background-size="cover"}

*Do or do not. There is no try*

::: {.incremental}

 - <span> **Interplay between different individual components of the System:** Impact of bed count, patient influx, and bed occupancy on patient wait times and bed utilization.</span>


 - <span> **Model Capabilities:** Our model effectively assesses the impact of bed availability on patient waiting times and bed utilization rates. </span>

 - <span> **Study Objective:** Enhancing resource allocation, minimizing patient wait times, and optimizing bed utilization for stroke patients.

:::

# <span> Limitations </span> 
::: {.incremental}

 - Model limitations: Assumptions on patient arrivals, stroke severity, and bed occupancy.


 - Model does not account for healthcare staff or medical equipment availability. 


 - Model simplifies complex reality: Actual situation may differ from assumptions.

:::

# <span> Future Enhancements </span> {.repeated-background-img style="background-image: url('david-becker-crs2vlkSe98-unsplash.jpg'); background-size: 100px 150px; background-repeat: repeat;"}

::: {.incremental}

 - Future enhancements to this model could include its extension to a broader healthcare simulation, assimilating other elements of hospital resources and facilities. 

 - Further, iterations could investigate the integration of machine learning methodologies for predicting patient loads and stroke severity distributions, thereby enhancing the decision-making process.
